Rich,
Kyo kanagu shi is =E4=BA=AC Kyoto =E9=87=91=E5=85=B7 metal fittings =
=E5=B8=A5 maker.  (Although dictionary definitions of this shi kanji are mo=
re like master or commander, I haven't seen it translated that way for this=
 compound term.)  I have seen it used as an attribution on both NTHK and NB=
THK origami.  

The meaning sounds rather similar to Kyo Kinko (=E4=BA=AC=
=E9=87=91=E5=B7=A5), or Kyoto metalsmith, but in practice usually designate=
s somewhat lower quality work.  A lot of mumei Edo period kozuka and kogai =
made in Goto style, but not actually Goto work, will get an attribution to =
Kyo Kinko.  Something that deviates further from Goto style and is a bit lo=
wer quality will be called Kyo Kanagushi.  That's not an exhaustive definit=
ion, but I hope it gives you some idea.  

A lot of Edo period kinko materi=
al isn't distinctive enough to allow an attribution to an individual or eve=
n a group.  For another example, a lot of later, average, unsigned menuki w=
ill be attributed to Kyo Kanagushi.  It's not necessarily bad stuff, but th=
ere's no way to identify it further.

Your kozuka is probably borderline fo=
r passing due to the quality and condition being a bit rough, but if it did=
, the attribution would likely be Kyo kanagu shi based on what I've observe=
d.

Jim




  Thanks for taking the time Jim. If I could ask, I am unfamilu=
ar with
  the term 京金具帥 Kyo-Kanagushi. Can you =
explain that please.

  kind regards

  Rich Turner
